question: Match the following:
column_I: Bees, butterflies, flies, beetles, wasps, ants, moths, birds (sunbirds and humming birds) and bats
Larger animals such as some primates (lemurs), arboreal rodents, reptiles (gecko lizard and garden lizard)
column_II: Common pollinating agents
Dominant biotic pollinating agents
Also reported as pollinators in some species
Specifically adapted for a particular species of animal

matches.left: Bees, butterflies, flies, beetles, wasps, ants, moths, birds (sunbirds and humming birds) and bats
matches.right: Common pollinating agents
Dominant biotic pollinating agents

matches.left: Larger animals such as some primates (lemurs), arboreal rodents, reptiles (gecko lizard and garden lizard)
matches.right: Also reported as pollinators in some species
Specifically adapted for a particular species of animal

answer: Bees, butterflies, flies, beetles, wasps, ants, moths, birds (sunbirds and humming birds) and bats → Common pollinating agents, Insects, particularly bees → Dominant biotic pollinating agents, Larger animals such as some primates (lemurs), arboreal rodents, reptiles (gecko lizard and garden lizard) → Also reported as pollinators in some species, Flowers of animal-pollinated plants → Specifically adapted for a particular species of animal

question: Match the following:
column_I: Flowers pollinated by flies and beetles
column_II: Large, colourful, fragrant and rich in nectar
Clustered into an inflorescence to make them conspicuous
Secrete foul odours to attract these animals
Nectar and pollen grains

matches.right: Large, colourful, fragrant and rich in nectar
Clustered into an inflorescence to make them conspicuous

matches.left: Flowers pollinated by flies and beetles
matches.right: Secrete foul odours to attract these animals
Nectar and pollen grains

answer: Majority of insect-pollinated flowers → Large, colourful, fragrant and rich in nectar, Small flowers → Clustered into an inflorescence to make them conspicuous, Flowers pollinated by flies and beetles → Secrete foul odours to attract these animals, Usual floral rewards → Nectar and pollen grains

question: Match the following:
column_I: Pollen grains in animal pollinated flowers
Relationship between a species of moth and the plant Yucca
column_II: Gets a coating of pollen grains
Generally sticky
Safe place to lay eggs; flower is about 6 feet in height
Both species cannot complete their life cycle without each other

matches.right: Gets a coating of pollen grains

matches.left: Pollen grains in animal pollinated flowers
matches.right: Generally sticky
Safe place to lay eggs; flower is about 6 feet in height

matches.left: Relationship between a species of moth and the plant Yucca
matches.right: Both species cannot complete their life cycle without each other

answer: Body of the animal visitor → Gets a coating of pollen grains, Pollen grains in animal pollinated flowers → Generally sticky, Floral reward in Amorphophallus → Safe place to lay eggs; flower is about 6 feet in height, Relationship between a species of moth and the plant Yucca → Both species cannot complete their life cycle without each other

question: Match the following:
column_I: Pollen release and stigma receptivity not synchronised
Anther and stigma placed at different positions
column_II: Prevents autogamy by releasing pollen before stigma is receptive or vice versa
Prevents autogamy by avoiding contact of pollen with stigma of same flower
Genetic mechanism preventing self-pollen from fertilising ovules
Prevents autogamy; in dioecy prevents both autogamy and geitonogamy

matches.left: Pollen release and stigma receptivity not synchronised
matches.right: Prevents autogamy by releasing pollen before stigma is receptive or vice versa

matches.left: Anther and stigma placed at different positions
matches.right: Prevents autogamy by avoiding contact of pollen with stigma of same flower
Genetic mechanism preventing self-pollen from fertilising ovules
Prevents autogamy; in dioecy prevents both autogamy and geitonogamy

answer: Pollen release and stigma receptivity not synchronised → Prevents autogamy by releasing pollen before stigma is receptive or vice versa, Anther and stigma placed at different positions → Prevents autogamy by avoiding contact of pollen with stigma of same flower, Self-incompatibility → Genetic mechanism preventing self-pollen from fertilising ovules, Unisexual flowers → Prevents autogamy; in dioecy prevents both autogamy and geitonogamy

question: Match the following:
column_I: Monoecious plants such as castor and maize
column_II: Male and female flowers on same plant; prevents autogamy but not geitonogamy
Male and female flowers on different plants; prevents both autogamy and geitonogamy
Rejected by pistil
Accepted by pistil and promotes post-pollination events

matches.left: Monoecious plants such as castor and maize
matches.right: Male and female flowers on same plant; prevents autogamy but not geitonogamy
Male and female flowers on different plants; prevents both autogamy and geitonogamy
Rejected by pistil
Accepted by pistil and promotes post-pollination events

answer: Monoecious plants such as castor and maize → Male and female flowers on same plant; prevents autogamy but not geitonogamy, Dioecious plants such as papaya → Male and female flowers on different plants; prevents both autogamy and geitonogamy, Wrong type of pollen → Rejected by pistil, Right type of pollen → Accepted by pistil and promotes post-pollination events
